nexttext:
where $E_{J }$ is the Josephson energy, and $\hat D[ \alpha (t)]$ is the cavity displacement operator (corresponding to a time-dependent displacement
$\alpha(t)$).
It is defined in terms of the photon annihilation operator $\hat{a}$ as

<math xmlns="http://www.w3.org/1998/Math/MathML" id="S0.E1.m1" class="ltx_Math" alttext="\hat{H}_{J}=-\frac{E_{J}}{2}\left(e^{2ieV_{\rm dc}t}\hat{D}[\alpha(t)]+e^{-2%
ieV_{\rm dc}t}\hat{D}^{\dagger}[\alpha(t)]\right)," display="block"><mrow><mrow><msub><mover accent="true"><mi>H</mi><mo stretchy="false">^</mo></mover><mi>J</mi></msub><mo>=</mo><mrow><mo>-</mo><mrow><mfrac><msub><mi>E</mi><mi>J</mi></msub><mn>2</mn></mfrac><mo>⁢</mo><mrow><mo>(</mo><mrow><mrow><msup><mi>e</mi><mrow><mn>2</mn><mo>⁢</mo><mi>i</mi><mo>⁢</mo><mi>e</mi><mo>⁢</mo><msub><mi>V</mi><mi>dc</mi></msub><mo>⁢</mo><mi>t</mi></mrow></msup><mo>⁢</mo><mover accent="true"><mi>D</mi><mo stretchy="false">^</mo></mover><mo>⁢</mo><mrow><mo stretchy="false">[</mo><mrow><mi>α</mi><mo>⁢</mo><mrow><mo stretchy="false">(</mo><mi>t</mi><mo stretchy="false">)</mo></mrow></mrow><mo stretchy="false">]</mo></mrow></mrow><mo>+</mo><mrow><msup><mi>e</mi><mrow><mo>-</mo><mrow><mn>2</mn><mo>⁢</mo><mi>i</mi><mo>⁢</mo><mi>e</mi><mo>⁢</mo><msub><mi>V</mi><mi>dc</mi></msub><mo>⁢</mo><mi>t</mi></mrow></mrow></msup><mo>⁢</mo><msup><mover accent="true"><mi>D</mi><mo stretchy="false">^</mo></mover><mo>†</mo></msup><mo>⁢</mo><mrow><mo stretchy="false">[</mo><mrow><mi>α</mi><mo>⁢</mo><mrow><mo stretchy="false">(</mo><mi>t</mi><mo stretchy="false">)</mo></mrow></mrow><mo stretchy="false">]</mo></mrow></mrow></mrow><mo>)</mo></mrow></mrow></mrow></mrow><mo>,</mo></mrow></math>

nexttext:
$\lambda$ determines the amplitude of the zero-point voltage fluctuations in the cavity, and is given by $\lambda=\sqrt{\pi e^2 Z/h }$ where $Z$ the impedance of the LC resonator.

From the point of view of the cavity, $\hat{H}_J$ describes a highly-nonlinear (but coherent) cavity drive \cite{PhysRevLett.111.247002}: each term tunnels a Cooper-pair, and also displaces the cavity state by $\pm \alpha(t)$.
To see clearly how these displacements can result in Fock state generation, we follow a different route from \cite{PhysRevLett.111.247002}, and
express $\hat D[\alpha(t)]$ directly in the Fock basis (see, e.g.~\cite{cahill1969ordered}):
prevtext:
where $E_{J }$ is the Josephson energy, and $\hat D[ \alpha (t)]$ is the cavity displacement operator (corresponding to a time-dependent displacement
$\alpha(t)$).
It is defined in terms of the photon annihilation operator $\hat{a}$ as
mathml:
<math xmlns="http://www.w3.org/1998/Math/MathML" id="S0.E2.m1" class="ltx_Math" alttext="\hat{D}[\alpha(t)]=e^{\alpha(t)\hat{a}^{\dagger}-\alpha^{*}(t)\hat{a}},\,\,%
\alpha(t)=2\lambda e^{i\omega_{\rm c}t}." display="block"><mrow><mrow><mrow><mrow><mover accent="true"><mi>D</mi><mo stretchy="false">^</mo></mover><mo>⁢</mo><mrow><mo stretchy="false">[</mo><mrow><mi>α</mi><mo>⁢</mo><mrow><mo stretchy="false">(</mo><mi>t</mi><mo stretchy="false">)</mo></mrow></mrow><mo stretchy="false">]</mo></mrow></mrow><mo>=</mo><msup><mi>e</mi><mrow><mrow><mi>α</mi><mo>⁢</mo><mrow><mo stretchy="false">(</mo><mi>t</mi><mo stretchy="false">)</mo></mrow><mo>⁢</mo><msup><mover accent="true"><mi>a</mi><mo stretchy="false">^</mo></mover><mo>†</mo></msup></mrow><mo>-</mo><mrow><msup><mi>α</mi><mo>*</mo></msup><mo>⁢</mo><mrow><mo stretchy="false">(</mo><mi>t</mi><mo stretchy="false">)</mo></mrow><mo>⁢</mo><mover accent="true"><mi>a</mi><mo stretchy="false">^</mo></mover></mrow></mrow></msup></mrow><mo rspace="5.9pt">,</mo><mrow><mrow><mi>α</mi><mo>⁢</mo><mrow><mo stretchy="false">(</mo><mi>t</mi><mo stretchy="false">)</mo></mrow></mrow><mo>=</mo><mrow><mn>2</mn><mo>⁢</mo><mi>λ</mi><mo>⁢</mo><msup><mi>e</mi><mrow><mi>i</mi><mo>⁢</mo><msub><mi>ω</mi><mi mathvariant="normal">c</mi></msub><mo>⁢</mo><mi>t</mi></mrow></msup></mrow></mrow></mrow><mo>.</mo></mrow></math>

For $l \geq 0$ we have:

$\lambda$ determines the amplitude of the zero-point voltage fluctuations in the cavity, and is given by $\lambda=\sqrt{\pi e^2 Z/h }$ where $Z$ the impedance of the LC resonator.

From the point of view of the cavity, $\hat{H}_J$ describes a highly-nonlinear (but coherent) cavity drive \cite{PhysRevLett.111.247002}: each term tunnels a Cooper-pair, and also displaces the cavity state by $\pm \alpha(t)$.
To see clearly how these displacements can result in Fock state generation, we follow a different route from \cite{PhysRevLett.111.247002}, and
express $\hat D[\alpha(t)]$ directly in the Fock basis (see, e.g.~\cite{cahill1969ordered}):

\displaystyle+\sum_{l=1}^{\infty}(-1)^{l}{|{n+l}\rangle}{\langle{n}|}w_{n+l,n}%
[\lambda]e^{il\omega_{\rm c}t}." display="block"><mtable displaystyle="true" rowspacing="0pt"><mtr><mtd columnalign="left"><mrow><mrow><mover accent="true"><mi>D</mi><mo where $L_{n}^{(k)}$ is a Laguerre polynomial \footnote{By convention, $1/(l+n)!=0$ for $l+n<0$}, and $w_{n+l,n}[\lambda]=w_{n,n+l}[-\lambda]$.

As is well known, Frank-Condon factors are highly nonlinear functions of the magnitude of the displacement (here set by $\lambda$), and can even exhibit zeros \cite{smith1968cancellation};  the behavior of relevant factors is shown Fig.~\ref{fig:qnl}.
We let ${\tilde{\lambda}}_{n+l,n}$ denote the smallest value of $\lambda$ which makes $w_{n+l,n}[\lambda]$ vanish:

For $l \geq 0$ we have:

<math xmlns="http://www.w3.org/1998/Math/MathML" id="S0.E4.m1" class="ltx_Math" alttext="w_{n+l,n}[\lambda]=e^{-2\lambda^{2}}(2\lambda)^{l}\sqrt{\tfrac{n!}{(n+l)!}}L_{%
n}^{(l)}(4\lambda^{2})," display="block"><mrow><mrow><mrow><msub><mi>w</mi><mrow><mrow><mi>n</mi><mo>+</mo><mi>l</mi></mrow><mo>,</mo><mi>n</mi></mrow></msub><mo>⁢</mo><mrow><mo stretchy="false">[</mo><mi>λ</mi><mo stretchy="false">]</mo></mrow></mrow><mo>=</mo><mrow><msup><mi>e</mi><mrow><mo>-</mo><mrow><mn>2</mn><mo>⁢</mo><msup><mi>λ</mi><mn>2</mn></msup></mrow></mrow></msup><mo>⁢</mo><msup><mrow><mo stretchy="false">(</mo><mrow><mn>2</mn><mo>⁢</mo><mi>λ</mi></mrow><mo stretchy="false">)</mo></mrow><mi>l</mi></msup><mo>⁢</mo><msqrt><mstyle displaystyle="false"><mfrac><mrow><mi>n</mi><mo lspace="0pt" rspace="3.5pt">!</mo></mrow><mrow><mrow><mo stretchy="false">(</mo><mrow><mi>n</mi><mo>+</mo><mi>l</mi></mrow><mo stretchy="false">)</mo></mrow><mo lspace="0pt" rspace="3.5pt">!</mo></mrow></mfrac></mstyle></msqrt><mo>⁢</mo><msubsup><mi>L</mi><mi>n</mi><mrow><mo stretchy="false">(</mo><mi>l</mi><mo stretchy="false">)</mo></mrow></msubsup><mo>⁢</mo><mrow><mo stretchy="false">(</mo><mrow><mn>4</mn><mo>⁢</mo><msup><mi>λ</mi><mn>2</mn></msup></mrow><mo stretchy="false">)</mo></mrow></mrow></mrow><mo>,</mo></mrow></math>

prevtext:
where $L_{n}^{(k)}$ is a Laguerre polynomial \footnote{By convention, $1/(l+n)!=0$ for $l+n<0$}, and $w_{n+l,n}[\lambda]=w_{n,n+l}[-\lambda]$.

As is well known, Frank-Condon factors are highly nonlinear functions of the magnitude of the displacement (here set by $\lambda$), and can even exhibit zeros \cite{smith1968cancellation};  the behavior of relevant factors is shown Fig.~\ref{fig:qnl}.
We let ${\tilde{\lambda}}_{n+l,n}$ denote the smallest value of $\lambda$ which makes $w_{n+l,n}[\lambda]$ vanish:
mathml: <math xmlns="http://www.w3.org/1998/Math/MathML" id="S0.E5.m1" class="ltx_Math" alttext="w_{n+l,n}[{\tilde{\lambda}}_{n+l,n}]=w_{n,n+l}[{\tilde{\lambda}}_{n+l,n}]=0." display="block"><mrow><mrow><mrow><msub><mi>w</mi><mrow><mrow><mi>n</mi><mo>+</mo><mi>l</mi></mrow><mo>,</mo><mi>n</mi></mrow></msub><mo>⁢</mo><mrow><mo stretchy="false">[</mo><msub><mover accent="true"><mi>λ</mi><mo stretchy="false">~</mo></mover><mrow><mrow><mi>n</mi><mo>+</mo><mi>l</mi></mrow><mo>,</mo><mi>n</mi></mrow></msub><mo stretchy="false">]</mo></mrow></mrow><mo>=</mo><mrow><msub><mi>w</mi><mrow><mi>n</mi><mo>,</mo><mrow><mi>n</mi><mo>+</mo><mi>l</mi></mrow></mrow></msub><mo>⁢</mo><mrow><mo stretchy="false">[</mo><msub><mover accent="true"><mi>λ</mi><mo stretchy="false">~</mo></mover><mrow><mrow><mi>n</mi><mo>+</mo><mi>l</mi></mrow><mo>,</mo><mi>n</mi></mrow></msub><mo stretchy="false">]</mo></mrow></mrow><mo>=</mo><mn>0</mn></mrow><mo>.</mo></mrow></math>

nexttext:
Consider the simplest case where $k=1$, and each resonantly-tunnelling Cooper pair emits or absorbs a singe cavity photon.
If we then set $\lambda = 1 / \sqrt{2} \equiv {\tilde{\lambda}}_{2,1}$, there is no matrix element in Eq.~(\ref{eq:hjrwa}) for a transition from $1$ to $2$ cavity photons.
As first discussed in Ref.~\cite{PhysRevLett.111.247002}, the junction induced drive now can add at most one photon to the cavity, implying that the system effectively acts like a driven two-level system.

The cavity steady-state is found by solving the Linblad master equation for the density matrix of the cavity $\hat \rho_{\rm c}$,
mathml:
<math xmlns="http://www.w3.org/1998/Math/MathML" id="S0.E6.m1" class="ltx_Math" alttext="\hat{H}_{\rm RWA}=(-1)^{k+1}\frac{E_{J}}{2}\sum_{n=0}^{\infty}w_{n+k,n}[%
\lambda]{|{n+k}\rangle}{\langle n|}+{\rm h.c.}." display="block"><mrow><mrow><mrow><msub><mover accent="true"><mi>H</mi><mo stretchy="false">^</mo></mover><mi>RWA</mi></msub><mo>=</mo><mrow><mrow><msup><mrow><mo stretchy="false">(</mo><mrow><mo>-</mo><mn>1</mn></mrow><mo stretchy="false">)</mo></mrow><mrow><mi>k</mi><mo>+</mo><mn>1</mn></mrow></msup><mo>⁢</mo><mfrac><msub><mi>E</mi><mi>J</mi></msub><mn>2</mn></mfrac><mo>⁢</mo><mrow><munderover><mo largeop="true" movablelimits="false" symmetric="true">∑</mo><mrow><mi>n</mi><mo>=</mo><mn>0</mn></mrow><mi mathvariant="normal">∞</mi></munderover><mrow><msub><mi>w</mi><mrow><mrow><mi>n</mi><mo>+</mo><mi>k</mi></mrow><mo>,</mo><mi>n</mi></mrow></msub><mo>⁢</mo><mrow><mo stretchy="false">[</mo><mi>λ</mi><mo stretchy="false">]</mo></mrow><mo>⁢</mo><mrow><mo fence="true" stretchy="false">|</mo><mrow><mi>n</mi><mo>+</mo><mi>k</mi></mrow><mo stretchy="false">⟩</mo></mrow><mo>⁢</mo><mrow><mo stretchy="false">⟨</mo><mi>n</mi><mo fence="true" stretchy="false">|</mo></mrow></mrow></mrow></mrow><mo>+</mo><mi mathvariant="normal">h</mi></mrow></mrow><mo>.</mo><mi mathvariant="normal">c</mi></mrow><mo>.</mo><mo>.</mo></mrow></math>

nexttext:
which includes the dissipation from the (zero-temperature) transmission line; here, ${\cal L}[\hat a]\hat\rho=\hat a \hat\rho \hat a ^{\dagger}-\tfrac12\{\hat \rho\hat n+\hat n\hat \rho\}$.
When $\lambda$ is set to ${\tilde{\lambda}}_{2,1}$, the stationary intracavity state can be termed non-classical, in that it results in a vanishing $g^{(2)}$ intensity-intensity correlation function \cite{PhysRevLett.111.247002}.
This simply reflects the fact that there is zero probability for having two or more photons in the cavity.
We are still far however from our goal of producing a single-photon Fock state.
As the cavity is effectively a driven two-level system, population inversion is impossible, and at best the steady state is an incoherent mixture having an equal probability of vacuum and single photon.
We stress that such a state exhibits no negativity in its Wigner function.

\textit{Fock state stabilization--  }
Heuristically, the poor performance of the single-cavity setup is easy to understand:  even if we eliminate the matrix element for ${| 1 \rangle} \rightarrow {| 2 \rangle}$ transitions, the junction-driven cavity continues to oscillates back and forth between the vacuum and the ${| 1 \rangle}$ Fock state (eventually relaxing into a mixed state).
To achieve true Fock state generation, one needs to shut off the oscillation dynamics when the system is in the ${| 1 \rangle}$ state.
As we now discuss, this can be achieved rather simply by coupling the junction to a second ``auxiliary" cavity (see Fig.~\ref{fig:schematics}) whose damping rate $\kappa_{\rm aux}$ is taken to be sufficiently large.

In what follows, we denote quantities for the main ``storage" cavity with a subscript ``s", while auxiliary cavity quantities have a subscript ``aux";  Fock states of the two-mode system are denoted ${| {n,m} \rangle}={| n \rangle}_{\rm s}\otimes {| m \rangle}_{\rm aux}$.
Working in an interaction picture with respect to the free cavity Hamitonians, the system Hamiltonian is ( here and throughout the text, $\hbar=1$),
prevtext:
Consider the simplest case where $k=1$, and each resonantly-tunnelling Cooper pair emits or absorbs a singe cavity photon.
If we then set $\lambda = 1 / \sqrt{2} \equiv {\tilde{\lambda}}_{2,1}$, there is no matrix element in Eq.~(\ref{eq:hjrwa}) for a transition from $1$ to $2$ cavity photons.
As first discussed in Ref.~\cite{PhysRevLett.111.247002}, the junction induced drive now can add at most one photon to the cavity, implying that the system effectively acts like a driven two-level system.

The cavity steady-state is found by solving the Linblad master equation for the density matrix of the cavity $\hat \rho_{\rm c}$,
mathml:
<math xmlns="http://www.w3.org/1998/Math/MathML" id="S0.E7.m1" class="ltx_Math" alttext="\dot{\hat{\rho}}_{\rm c}=-i[\hat{H}_{\rm RWA},\hat{\rho}_{\rm c}]+\kappa{\cal L%
}[\hat{a}]\hat{\rho}_{\rm c}," display="block"><mrow><mrow><msub><mover accent="true"><mover accent="true"><mi>ρ</mi><mo stretchy="false">^</mo></mover><mo>˙</mo></mover><mi mathvariant="normal">c</mi></msub><mo>=</mo><mrow><mrow><mo>-</mo><mrow><mi>i</mi><mo>⁢</mo><mrow><mo stretchy="false">[</mo><msub><mover accent="true"><mi>H</mi><mo stretchy="false">^</mo></mover><mi>RWA</mi></msub><mo>,</mo><msub><mover accent="true"><mi>ρ</mi><mo stretchy="false">^</mo></mover><mi mathvariant="normal">c</mi></msub><mo stretchy="false">]</mo></mrow></mrow></mrow><mo>+</mo><mrow><mi>κ</mi><mo>⁢</mo><mi class="ltx_font_mathcaligraphic">ℒ</mi><mo>⁢</mo><mrow><mo stretchy="false">[</mo><mover accent="true"><mi>a</mi><mo stretchy="false">^</mo></mover><mo stretchy="false">]</mo></mrow><mo>⁢</mo><msub><mover accent="true"><mi>ρ</mi><mo stretchy="false">^</mo></mover><mi mathvariant="normal">c</mi></msub></mrow></mrow></mrow><mo>,</mo></mrow></math>

nexttext:
Here $\hat{\cal D}[\alpha_{\rm s}(t),\alpha_{\rm aux}(t)]=\hat D_{\rm s}[\alpha_{\rm s}(t)]\otimes\hat D_{\rm aux}[\alpha_{\rm aux}(t)]$ is the tensor product of displacement operators for each cavity, with respective displacement amplitudes $\alpha_{j}(t)=2\lambda_{j} e^{i \omega_{j} t}$.

For the auxiliary cavity to play the desired role, we tune the voltage so that $V_{\rm dc}=(\omega_{\rm s}+\omega_{\rm aux})/2e$.  Cooper-pair tunnelling thus requires simultaneously emitting a single photon to each cavity (or absorbing a photon from each cavity).
We also tune the storage cavity impedance so that $\lambda_{\rm s} = {\tilde{\lambda}}_{2,1}$; we stress that no special tuning of $\lambda_{\rm aux}$ is needed.
The resulting dynamics is sketched in Fig.~\ref{fig:PP_v2}b.
Similar to the single-cavity system, the effective driving from the biased junction couples ${| {0,0} \rangle}$ to ${| {1,1} \rangle}$, but
not to states with higher photon number.
We would seem yet again to have an effective two-level system, and might expect coherent oscillations between these two states.
However, the large damping rate $\kappa_{\rm aux}$ of the auxiliary cavity prevents this:  if the system is in the ${| {1,1} \rangle}$ state, $\kappa_{\rm aux}$ will cause a rapid decay to ${| {1,0} \rangle}$.
In the absence of storage cavity damping, the system is then effectively stuck:  Cooper-pair tunnelling against the voltage is impossible (as there are no photons in the aux cavity), while tunnelling with the voltage is impossible as there is no matrix element connecting ${| {1,0} \rangle}$ and ${| {2,1} \rangle}$.
Including storage cavity-damping does not ruin the physics:  if the storage cavity photon leaks out, one is back in the vacuum state, and the process starts again.
One thus sees the possibility for having a steady state that has a high fidelity with the state ${| {1,0} \rangle}$, i.e. a stabilized single-photon state in the storage cavity.

\begin{figure}[t]
	\centering
\includegraphics[width=.47\textwidth]{PhysicalPicture_v4.pdf}
	\caption{\label{fig:PP_v2} Schematic depictions of biased-junction cavity pumping processes.  The boxed digit indicates the number of Cooper pairs that have tunnelled, whereas dots in the parabolas indicate intracavity photon number.  a) Single cavity setup for an impedance yielding $\lambda = \tilde{\lambda}_{2,1}$.  Cooper-pair tunnelling can take the cavity between the 0 and 1 photon states, but transitions to the 2-photon state are blocked.
	 b) Two-cavity setup for Fock state stabilization, where $\lambda_{\rm s} = {\tilde{\lambda}}_{2,1}$.  Starting from vacuum, Cooper-pair tunneling can cause oscillations between the ${| {0,0} \rangle}$ and ${| {1,1} \rangle}$ photon Fock states.  Photon decay from the aux cavity however freezes the system into the desired ${| {1,0} \rangle}$ state.  When the storage cavity photon decays (due to $\kappa_{\rm s}$), the cycle repeats.  }
\end{figure}

\begin{figure}
		\centering
		\includegraphics[width=.482\textwidth]{JJ2cav_v5.pdf}
	\caption{\label{fig:2-4Photons} Steady-state probability $p_{\rm s}[n]$ for the storage cavity to be in a Fock state ${| {n} \rangle}$, as obtained
	from the RWA master equation in Eq.~(\ref{eq:RWAMaster}).  We take $E_{ J}=\kappa_{\rm aux} \ll \omega_{\rm s}, \omega_{\rm aux}$,
	and $\lambda_{\rm aux} = 1/2$; $\lambda_{\rm s}$ and $\kappa_{\rm s}$ are indicated in the plots.
	(a) Probabilities when $\lambda_{\rm s}$ is tuned close to ${\tilde{\lambda}}_{2,1}$ (for stabilizing ${| {1} \rangle}$).  (b)  Same, for
		$\lambda_{\rm s}$ tuned close to ${\tilde{\lambda}}_{3,2}$ (for stabilizing ${| {2} \rangle}$).  Even with imperfect tuning, the target Fock state is stabilized with a high fidelity.
		(c) and (d) Corresponding Wigner function $W[\upalpha]$ for the storage cavity state, showing that negative values are obtained; note that $W[\upalpha]$ is rotationally invariant in all cases.
		}
\end{figure}

To make the above picture quantitative, we focus on a voltage $V_{\rm dc}=(\omega_{\rm aux}+\omega_{\rm s})/2e$, and make a RWA on our Hamiltonian, yielding:
prevtext:
which includes the dissipation from the (zero-temperature) transmission line; here, ${\cal L}[\hat a]\hat\rho=\hat a \hat\rho \hat a ^{\dagger}-\tfrac12\{\hat \rho\hat n+\hat n\hat \rho\}$.
When $\lambda$ is set to ${\tilde{\lambda}}_{2,1}$, the stationary intracavity state can be termed non-classical, in that it results in a vanishing $g^{(2)}$ intensity-intensity correlation function \cite{PhysRevLett.111.247002}.
This simply reflects the fact that there is zero probability for having two or more photons in the cavity.
We are still far however from our goal of producing a single-photon Fock state.
As the cavity is effectively a driven two-level system, population inversion is impossible, and at best the steady state is an incoherent mixture having an equal probability of vacuum and single photon.
We stress that such a state exhibits no negativity in its Wigner function.

\textit{Fock state stabilization--  }
Heuristically, the poor performance of the single-cavity setup is easy to understand:  even if we eliminate the matrix element for ${| 1 \rangle} \rightarrow {| 2 \rangle}$ transitions, the junction-driven cavity continues to oscillates back and forth between the vacuum and the ${| 1 \rangle}$ Fock state (eventually relaxing into a mixed state).
To achieve true Fock state generation, one needs to shut off the oscillation dynamics when the system is in the ${| 1 \rangle}$ state.
As we now discuss, this can be achieved rather simply by coupling the junction to a second ``auxiliary" cavity (see Fig.~\ref{fig:schematics}) whose damping rate $\kappa_{\rm aux}$ is taken to be sufficiently large.

In what follows, we denote quantities for the main ``storage" cavity with a subscript ``s", while auxiliary cavity quantities have a subscript ``aux";  Fock states of the two-mode system are denoted ${| {n,m} \rangle}={| n \rangle}_{\rm s}\otimes {| m \rangle}_{\rm aux}$.
Working in an interaction picture with respect to the free cavity Hamitonians, the system Hamiltonian is ( here and throughout the text, $\hbar=1$),
mathml:
<math xmlns="http://www.w3.org/1998/Math/MathML" id="S0.E8.m1" class="ltx_Math" alttext="\hat{\cal H}_{J}=-\tfrac{E_{J}}{2}e^{2ieV_{\rm dc}t}\hat{\cal D}[\alpha_{\rm s%
}(t),\alpha_{\rm aux}(t)]+{\rm h.c.}." display="block"><mrow><mrow><mrow><msub><mover accent="true"><mi class="ltx_font_mathcaligraphic">ℋ</mi><mo stretchy="false">^</mo></mover><mi>J</mi></msub><mo>=</mo><mrow><mrow><mo>-</mo><mrow><mstyle displaystyle="false"><mfrac><msub><mi>E</mi><mi>J</mi></msub><mn>2</mn></mfrac></mstyle><mo>⁢</mo><msup><mi>e</mi><mrow><mn>2</mn><mo>⁢</mo><mi>i</mi><mo>⁢</mo><mi>e</mi><mo>⁢</mo><msub><mi>V</mi><mi>dc</mi></msub><mo>⁢</mo><mi>t</mi></mrow></msup><mo>⁢</mo><mover accent="true"><mi class="ltx_font_mathcaligraphic">𝒟</mi><mo stretchy="false">^</mo></mover><mo>⁢</mo><mrow><mo stretchy="false">[</mo><mrow><msub><mi>α</mi><mi mathvariant="normal">s</mi></msub><mo>⁢</mo><mrow><mo stretchy="false">(</mo><mi>t</mi><mo stretchy="false">)</mo></mrow></mrow><mo>,</mo><mrow><msub><mi>α</mi><mi>aux</mi></msub><mo>⁢</mo><mrow><mo stretchy="false">(</mo><mi>t</mi><mo stretchy="false">)</mo></mrow></mrow><mo stretchy="false">]</mo></mrow></mrow></mrow><mo>+</mo><mi mathvariant="normal">h</mi></mrow></mrow><mo>.</mo><mi mathvariant="normal">c</mi></mrow><mo>.</mo><mo>.</mo></mrow></math>

nexttext: Each cavity is also coupled to its own zero temperature bath, and the reduced density matrix $\hat \rho$ of the two cavities obeys the Linblad master equation:
prevtext:
Here $\hat{\cal D}[\alpha_{\rm s}(t),\alpha_{\rm aux}(t)]=\hat D_{\rm s}[\alpha_{\rm s}(t)]\otimes\hat D_{\rm aux}[\alpha_{\rm aux}(t)]$ is the tensor product of displacement operators for each cavity, with respective displacement amplitudes $\alpha_{j}(t)=2\lambda_{j} e^{i \omega_{j} t}$.

For the auxiliary cavity to play the desired role, we tune the voltage so that $V_{\rm dc}=(\omega_{\rm s}+\omega_{\rm aux})/2e$.  Cooper-pair tunnelling thus requires simultaneously emitting a single photon to each cavity (or absorbing a photon from each cavity).
We also tune the storage cavity impedance so that $\lambda_{\rm s} = {\tilde{\lambda}}_{2,1}$; we stress that no special tuning of $\lambda_{\rm aux}$ is needed.
The resulting dynamics is sketched in Fig.~\ref{fig:PP_v2}b.
Similar to the single-cavity system, the effective driving from the biased junction couples ${| {0,0} \rangle}$ to ${| {1,1} \rangle}$, but
not to states with higher photon number.
We would seem yet again to have an effective two-level system, and might expect coherent oscillations between these two states.
However, the large damping rate $\kappa_{\rm aux}$ of the auxiliary cavity prevents this:  if the system is in the ${| {1,1} \rangle}$ state, $\kappa_{\rm aux}$ will cause a rapid decay to ${| {1,0} \rangle}$.
In the absence of storage cavity damping, the system is then effectively stuck:  Cooper-pair tunnelling against the voltage is impossible (as there are no photons in the aux cavity), while tunnelling with the voltage is impossible as there is no matrix element connecting ${| {1,0} \rangle}$ and ${| {2,1} \rangle}$.
Including storage cavity-damping does not ruin the physics:  if the storage cavity photon leaks out, one is back in the vacuum state, and the process starts again.
One thus sees the possibility for having a steady state that has a high fidelity with the state ${| {1,0} \rangle}$, i.e. a stabilized single-photon state in the storage cavity.

\begin{figure}[t]
	\centering
\includegraphics[width=.47\textwidth]{PhysicalPicture_v4.pdf}
	\caption{\label{fig:PP_v2} Schematic depictions of biased-junction cavity pumping processes.  The boxed digit indicates the number of Cooper pairs that have tunnelled, whereas dots in the parabolas indicate intracavity photon number.  a) Single cavity setup for an impedance yielding $\lambda = \tilde{\lambda}_{2,1}$.  Cooper-pair tunnelling can take the cavity between the 0 and 1 photon states, but transitions to the 2-photon state are blocked.
	 b) Two-cavity setup for Fock state stabilization, where $\lambda_{\rm s} = {\tilde{\lambda}}_{2,1}$.  Starting from vacuum, Cooper-pair tunneling can cause oscillations between the ${| {0,0} \rangle}$ and ${| {1,1} \rangle}$ photon Fock states.  Photon decay from the aux cavity however freezes the system into the desired ${| {1,0} \rangle}$ state.  When the storage cavity photon decays (due to $\kappa_{\rm s}$), the cycle repeats.  }
\end{figure}

\begin{figure}
		\centering
		\includegraphics[width=.482\textwidth]{JJ2cav_v5.pdf}
	\caption{\label{fig:2-4Photons} Steady-state probability $p_{\rm s}[n]$ for the storage cavity to be in a Fock state ${| {n} \rangle}$, as obtained
	from the RWA master equation in Eq.~(\ref{eq:RWAMaster}).  We take $E_{ J}=\kappa_{\rm aux} \ll \omega_{\rm s}, \omega_{\rm aux}$,
	and $\lambda_{\rm aux} = 1/2$; $\lambda_{\rm s}$ and $\kappa_{\rm s}$ are indicated in the plots.
	(a) Probabilities when $\lambda_{\rm s}$ is tuned close to ${\tilde{\lambda}}_{2,1}$ (for stabilizing ${| {1} \rangle}$).  (b)  Same, for
		$\lambda_{\rm s}$ tuned close to ${\tilde{\lambda}}_{3,2}$ (for stabilizing ${| {2} \rangle}$).  Even with imperfect tuning, the target Fock state is stabilized with a high fidelity.
		(c) and (d) Corresponding Wigner function $W[\upalpha]$ for the storage cavity state, showing that negative values are obtained; note that $W[\upalpha]$ is rotationally invariant in all cases.
		}
\end{figure}

To make the above picture quantitative, we focus on a voltage $V_{\rm dc}=(\omega_{\rm aux}+\omega_{\rm s})/2e$, and make a RWA on our Hamiltonian, yielding:
mathml:
<math xmlns="http://www.w3.org/1998/Math/MathML" id="S0.E9.m1" class="ltx_Math" alttext="\displaystyle\hat{\cal H}_{\rm RWA}=\frac{E_{J}}{2}\left(\sum_{n_{\rm s}=0}^{%
\infty}w_{n_{\rm s}+1,n_{\rm s}}[\lambda]{|{n_{\rm s}+1}\rangle}{\langle{n_{%
\rm s}}|}\right)\\
\displaystyle\otimes\left(\sum_{n_{\rm aux}=0}^{\infty}w_{n_{\rm aux}+1,n_{\rm
aux%
}}[\lambda]{|{n_{\rm aux}+1}\rangle}{\langle{n_{\rm aux}}|}\right)+{\rm h.c.}." display="block"><mtable displaystyle="true" rowspacing="0pt"><mtr><mtd columnalign="left"><mrow><msub><mover accent="true"><mi class="ltx_font_mathcaligraphic">ℋ</mi><mo stretchy="false">^</mo></mover><mi>RWA</mi></msub><mo>=</mo><mrow><mfrac><msub><mi>E</mi><mi>J</mi></msub><mn>2</mn></mfrac><mo>⁢</mo><mrow><mo>(</mo><mrow><munderover><mo largeop="true" movablelimits="false" symmetric="true">∑</mo><mrow><msub><mi>n</mi><mi mathvariant="normal">s</mi></msub><mo>=</mo><mn>0</mn></mrow><mi mathvariant="normal">∞</mi></munderover><mrow><msub><mi>w</mi><mrow><mrow><msub><mi>n</mi><mi mathvariant="normal">s</mi></msub><mo>+</mo><mn>1</mn></mrow><mo>,</mo><msub><mi>n</mi><mi mathvariant="normal">s</mi></msub></mrow></msub><mo>⁢</mo><mrow><mo stretchy="false">[</mo><mi>λ</mi><mo stretchy="false">]</mo></mrow><mo>⁢</mo><mrow><mo fence="true" stretchy="false">|</mo><mrow><msub><mi>n</mi><mi mathvariant="normal">s</mi></msub><mo>+</mo><mn>1</mn></mrow><mo stretchy="false">⟩</mo></mrow><mo>⁢</mo><mrow><mo stretchy="false">⟨</mo><msub><mi>n</mi><mi mathvariant="normal">s</mi></msub><mo fence="true" stretchy="false">|</mo></mrow></mrow></mrow><mo>)</mo></mrow></mrow></mrow></mtd></mtr><mtr><mtd columnalign="right"><mrow><mo>⊗</mo><mrow><mo>(</mo><munderover><mo largeop="true" movablelimits="false" symmetric="true">∑</mo><mrow><msub><mi>n</mi><mi>aux</mi></msub><mo>=</mo><mn>0</mn></mrow><mi mathvariant="normal">∞</mi></munderover><msub><mi>w</mi><mrow><mrow><msub><mi>n</mi><mi>aux</mi></msub><mo>+</mo><mn>1</mn></mrow><mo>,</mo><msub><mi>n</mi><mi>aux</mi></msub></mrow></msub><mrow><mo stretchy="false">[</mo><mi>λ</mi><mo stretchy="false">]</mo></mrow><mo stretchy="false">|</mo><msub><mi>n</mi><mi>aux</mi></msub><mo>+</mo><mn>1</mn><mo stretchy="false">⟩</mo></mrow><mrow><mo stretchy="false">⟨</mo><msub><mi>n</mi><mi>aux</mi></msub><mo stretchy="false">|</mo><mo>)</mo></mrow><mo>+</mo><mi mathvariant="normal">h</mi><mo>.</mo><mi mathvariant="normal">c</mi><mo>.</mo><mo>.</mo></mrow></mtd></mtr></mtable></math>

nexttext: Consider first the ideal case, where $\lambda_{\rm s}$ is tuned perfectly to equal ${\tilde{\lambda}}_{2,1}$.  In the relevant limit $\kappa_{\rm s} \ll \kappa_{\rm aux}$, the steady state probability that the system is in the desired state ${| {1,0} \rangle}$ is
prevtext: Each cavity is also coupled to its own zero temperature bath, and the reduced density matrix $\hat \rho$ of the two cavities obeys the Linblad master equation:
mathml:
<math xmlns="http://www.w3.org/1998/Math/MathML" id="S0.E10.m1" class="ltx_Math" alttext="\dot{\hat{\rho}}=-i[\hat{H}_{\rm RWA},\hat{\rho}]+\kappa_{\rm aux}{\cal L}[%
\hat{a}_{\rm aux}]\hat{\rho}+\kappa_{\rm s}{\cal L}[\hat{a}_{\rm s}]\hat{\rho}." display="block"><mrow><mrow><mover accent="true"><mover accent="true"><mi>ρ</mi><mo stretchy="false">^</mo></mover><mo>˙</mo></mover><mo>=</mo><mrow><mrow><mo>-</mo><mrow><mi>i</mi><mo>⁢</mo><mrow><mo stretchy="false">[</mo><msub><mover accent="true"><mi>H</mi><mo stretchy="false">^</mo></mover><mi>RWA</mi></msub><mo>,</mo><mover accent="true"><mi>ρ</mi><mo stretchy="false">^</mo></mover><mo stretchy="false">]</mo></mrow></mrow></mrow><mo>+</mo><mrow><msub><mi>κ</mi><mi>aux</mi></msub><mo>⁢</mo><mi class="ltx_font_mathcaligraphic">ℒ</mi><mo>⁢</mo><mrow><mo stretchy="false">[</mo><msub><mover accent="true"><mi>a</mi><mo stretchy="false">^</mo></mover><mi>aux</mi></msub><mo stretchy="false">]</mo></mrow><mo>⁢</mo><mover accent="true"><mi>ρ</mi><mo stretchy="false">^</mo></mover></mrow><mo>+</mo><mrow><msub><mi>κ</mi><mi mathvariant="normal">s</mi></msub><mo>⁢</mo><mi class="ltx_font_mathcaligraphic">ℒ</mi><mo>⁢</mo><mrow><mo stretchy="false">[</mo><msub><mover accent="true"><mi>a</mi><mo stretchy="false">^</mo></mover><mi mathvariant="normal">s</mi></msub><mo stretchy="false">]</mo></mrow><mo>⁢</mo><mover accent="true"><mi>ρ</mi><mo stretchy="false">^</mo></mover></mrow></mrow></mrow><mo>.</mo></mrow></math>

nexttext:
where $\Gamma$ plays the role of an effective pumping rate from ${| {0,0} \rangle}$ to ${| {1,0} \rangle}$, and we have dropped terms as small as $\kappa_{\rm s} / \kappa_{\rm aux}$.  The probability to be in the desired state tends to $1$ in the limit $\Gamma \gg \kappa_{\rm aux} \gg \kappa_s$.  The large ${| {1,0} \rangle}$ population here is analogous to the population inversion possible in a driven three-level system \cite{walls2007quantum}.

The above process can be efficient even if the storage cavity impedance is not perfectly tuned.  Suppose $\lambda_{\rm s}={\tilde{\lambda}}_{2,1}+\varepsilon$ with $\varepsilon\ll1$.  Assuming again $\kappa_{\rm s}\ll \kappa_{\rm aux}$, one finds that the probability to be in ${| {1,0} \rangle}$ is modified to be:

s%
}},\hskip 8.535827pt\Gamma=\frac{\left(E_{J}w_{1,0}[\lambda_{\rm s}]w_{1,0}[%
\lambda_{\rm aux}]\right)^{2}}{\kappa_{\rm aux}}," display="block"><mrow><mrow><mrow><mrow><mo stretchy="false">⟨</mo><mrow><mn>1</mn><mo>,</mo><mn>0</mn></mrow><mo fence="true" stretchy="false">|</mo><mover accent="true"><mi>ρ</mi><mo stretchy="false">^</mo></mover><mo fence="true" stretchy="false">|</mo><mrow><mn>1</mn><mo>,</mo><mn>0</mn></mrow><mo stretchy="false">⟩</mo></mrow><mo>≃</mo><mfrac><mi mathvariant="normal">Γ</mi><mrow><mi mathvariant="normal">Γ</mi><mo>+</mo><msub><mi>κ</mi><mi mathvariant="normal">s</mi></msub></mrow></mfrac></mrow><mo rspace="11pt">,</mo><mrow><mi mathvariant="normal">Γ</mi><mo>=</mo><mfrac><msup><mrow><mo>(</mo><mrow><msub><mi>E</mi><mi>J</mi></msub><mo>⁢</mo><msub><mi>w</mi><mrow><mn>1</mn><mo>,</mo><mn>0</mn></mrow></msub><mo>⁢</mo><mrow><mo stretchy="false">[</mo><msub><mi>λ</mi><mi mathvariant="normal">s</mi></msub><mo stretchy="false">]</mo></mrow><mo>⁢</mo><msub><mi>w</mi><mrow><mn>1</mn><mo>,</mo><mn>0</mn></mrow></msub><mo>⁢</mo><mrow><mo stretchy="false">[</mo><msub><mi>λ</mi><mi>aux</mi></msub><mo stretchy="false">]</mo></mrow></mrow><mo>)</mo></mrow><mn>2</mn></msup><msub><mi>κ</mi><mi>aux</mi></msub></mfrac></mrow></mrow><mo>,</mo></mrow></math>

prevtext:
where $\Gamma$ plays the role of an effective pumping rate from ${| {0,0} \rangle}$ to ${| {1,0} \rangle}$, and we have dropped terms as small as $\kappa_{\rm s} / \kappa_{\rm aux}$.  The probability to be in the desired state tends to $1$ in the limit $\Gamma \gg \kappa_{\rm aux} \gg \kappa_s$.  The large ${| {1,0} \rangle}$ population here is analogous to the population inversion possible in a driven three-level system \cite{walls2007quantum}.

The above process can be efficient even if the storage cavity impedance is not perfectly tuned.  Suppose $\lambda_{\rm s}={\tilde{\lambda}}_{2,1}+\varepsilon$ with $\varepsilon\ll1$.  Assuming again $\kappa_{\rm s}\ll \kappa_{\rm aux}$, one finds that the probability to be in ${| {1,0} \rangle}$ is modified to be:

<math xmlns="http://www.w3.org/1998/Math/MathML" id="S0.E12.m1" class="ltx_Math" alttext="{\langle{1,0}|}\hat{\rho}{|{1,0}\rangle}\simeq\frac{\Gamma}{\Gamma+\kappa_{\rm
s%
}+4\varepsilon^{2}\Gamma^{2}/\kappa_{\rm s}}." display="block"><mrow><mrow><mrow><mo stretchy="false">⟨</mo><mrow><mn>1</mn><mo>,</mo><mn>0</mn></mrow><mo fence="true" stretchy="false">|</mo><mover accent="true"><mi>ρ</mi><mo stretchy="false">^</mo></mover><mo fence="true" stretchy="false">|</mo><mrow><mn>1</mn><mo>,</mo><mn>0</mn></mrow><mo stretchy="false">⟩</mo></mrow><mo>≃</mo><mfrac><mi mathvariant="normal">Γ</mi><mrow><mi mathvariant="normal">Γ</mi><mo>+</mo><msub><mi>κ</mi><mi mathvariant="normal">s</mi></msub><mo>+</mo><mrow><mrow><mn>4</mn><mo>⁢</mo><msup><mi>ε</mi><mn>2</mn></msup><mo>⁢</mo><msup><mi mathvariant="normal">Γ</mi><mn>2</mn></msup></mrow><mo>/</mo><msub><mi>κ</mi><mi mathvariant="normal">s</mi></msub></mrow></mrow></mfrac></mrow><mo>.</mo></mrow></math>
